Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the SoLEAP Program at Old Dominion University (ODU) is to provide academic, social and financial support to approximately 36 talented, motivated, and financially-needy students enrolled in the photovoltaic Solar Engineering Academic Program (SoLEAP). SoLEAP at ODU impacts student success and addresses the urgent need for well-trained energy scientists and engineers at both regional and national levels. SoLEAP scholars receive access to innovative academic training, mentoring, and career development/transition programs that help them enter into the solar energy sectors with the expertise needed for successful careers. The program expands and advances the solar engineering workforce to become globally competitive in photovoltaic industries.

The SoLEAP program at Old Dominion University is an educational program that incorporates innovative academic strategies with resources needed to prepare undergraduate and graduate students to confront problems in the rapidly changing field of photovoltaic technology. The academic support approach combines virtual and physical hands-on activities and project based learning. Student support programs are improved by using reciprocal mentoring/peer mentoring programs and social networking by a peer-learning community of students. Academic success is fostered through support provided for career development and career transitions through collaborative research and industry-based projects with local industry partners, academic and national laboratories. The comprehensive academic training and mentoring programs prepares students with the skill sets essential to photovoltaic technologies. To maximize student learning, integrated modules of theory, virtual learning, and hands-on experience complement theory-based lectures with project-based learning. In addition, reciprocal mentoring between students and faculty/industrial partners is practiced for transformative support of success in completing degrees, career counseling, development, and transition. A SoLEAP mentoring cohort consisting of undergraduates and graduates forms reciprocal and peer mentoring networks in which more experienced students mentor less experienced peers. SoLEAP offers comprehensive training and career development programs to help students as they transition between their academic and professional careers. The project includes efforts to make the project results known to the broader STEM education community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF S-STEM SoLEAP (Solar Engineering Academic Program) provided academic, social and financial support to talented, motivated, and financially-needy students enrolled in photovoltaic and microelectronic programs at Old Dominion University (ODU). Particularly, SoLEAP at ODU offered new photovoltaic curriculum and hands-on research opportunities for SoLEAP Scholars to develop professional skill sets and expertise needed for successful careers.

The intellectual merits of this proposal lie in the four goals of this project:

Goal 1.    Enhance and increase the number of talented, motived, and financially-needy students preparing for careers in solar energy engineering technologies

Goal 2.    Improve academic support through ODU’s innovative instructional approach, which combines virtual and physical hands-on activities and a proven academic model of project-based learning.

Goal 3.    Improve student support programs using reciprocal mentoring/peer mentoring (RM/PM) programs and social networking by developing a peer-learning community of students.

Goal 4.    Foster academic success and provide career development and career transition support through collaborative research and industry-based projects with local industry partners, academic and national laboratories.

 Outcomes related to intellectual merits are

  1. SoLEAP supported forty-five SoLEAP scholars for five years. Among them, thirty were undergraduates and fifteen were MS/Ph.D. students. Female SoLEAP scholars were ten, taking account for 22.2% of the SoLEAP population.
  2. One-on-one mentoring was offered to SoLEAP students through the year to guide students' academic excellence, mentor research projects and council job opportunities in the engineering fields. Most undergraduate SoLEAP students undertook undergraduate research or senior design projects while some SoLEAP students were connected to other researchers for their undergraduate research. Particularly, some undergraduate SoLEAP students who participated in photovoltaic research involved publishing their works to high impact journals.
  3. To support student retention and academic excellence, SoLEAP reciprocal/peer mentoring networks consisting of undergraduates, graduate students, and faculties were built. Through reciprocal mentoring practice, SoLEAP students obtained advice, a broader perspective and expertise, and helpful direction in their research and academic training. This approach highly motivated many SoLEAP undergraduate students to have academic excellence and pursue graduate programs.
  4. The SoLEAP students improved their GPA after receiving SoLEAP scholarship, mentoring and academic support. Before SoLEAP scholarship was awarded, the average GPA was 3.34. However, after SoLEAP scholars received financial and academic supports, the average GPA of 45 SoLEAP scholars was slightly increased to 3.42  

Broader impacts:

We promoted academic success and provided career development and career transition support through collaborative research and research-based projects. SoLEAP students were offered seminars related to photovoltaic technologies, cohort meeting, and mentoring. In addition, SoLEAP students were required to take courses designed to provide hands-on experiments that helped students to raise critical skills necessary for professional careers. Graduated SoLEAP students continued their profession careers at Kennedy Space Center, NAVSEA, other national laboratories or related industries such as WSP, Huntington Ingalls Industries, Swisslog Controls, JP Harvey Engineering Solutions and others. Seven journal papers and one conference proceeding were published, and three presentations were made.
